text:
Jefferson Market, Sixth Avenue at 9th Street. Also the Fire Tower.

1866.

H. W. Tiemann Company
Brown Brothers

(1)
Sixth Avenue, east side, at 9th Street, showing the new West Side Savings Bank building (erected 1928) on the N.E. corner of 9th Street. It contains the entrance to the Hudson and Manhattan railroad to New Jersey.
In the foreground is shown part of the old Jefferson Market Court House building and the excavation caused by demolition of the old Jefferson Market and construction of the municipal subway. On this site the new House of Detention for Women is to be built. To the right is the 8th Street Station of the Sixth Avenue Elevated Line.
On the skyline in the left of the picture are 55 Fifth Avenue, the Consolidated Gas building on 14th Street east of Irving Place, and the tower of the new 40 Fifth Avenue apartment building on the S.W. corner of 11th Street. In the right background may be seen the new One Fifth Avenue apartment hotel at 8th Street, and the skeleton of the new apartment building under construction at 1 University Place, opposite the N.E. corner of Washington Square.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, a closer view.

P. L. Sperr.

December 31, 1929.

(1)
Sixth Avenue, east side, at 9th Street, showing the new West Side Savings Bank building (erected 1928) on the N.E. corner of 9th Street. It contains the entrance to the Hudson and Manhattan railroad to New Jersey.
In the foreground is shown part of the old Jefferson Market Court House building and the excavation caused by demolition of the old Jefferson Market and construction of the municipal subway. On this site the new House of Detention for Women is to be built. To the right is the 8th Street Station of the Sixth Avenue Elevated Line.
On the skyline in the left of the picture are 55 Fifth Avenue, the Consolidated Gas building on 14th Street east of Irving Place, and the tower of the new 40 Fifth Avenue apartment building on the S.W. corner of 11th Street. In the right background may be seen the new One Fifth Avenue apartment hotel at 8th Street, and the skeleton of the new apartment building under construction at 1 University Place, opposite the N.E. corner of Washington Square.

P. L. Sperr.

December 31, 1929.

East side of Sixth Avenue looking north from 9th Street.
March 29, 1933.
P.L. Sperr, Photographer.

9th Street adjoining N.E. corner of Fourth Avenue, showing the second-hand bookstores which are found throughout this neighborhood. In them bibliophiles with limited funds seeks but seldom find rare books at give-away prices.

June 12, 1933.

P.L. Sperr.

9th Street at S.E. corner of Sixth Avenue, showing Nos. 52-68 West 9th Street.

May 24, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

430 Sixth Ave., east side, between West 9th and 10th Streets, showing a florist occupying an entrance to this building. This structure formerly bore No. 118-122 Sixth Ave. No. 2 of this set is similar.

September 18, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

B1 NEG: 2807

430 Sixth Ave., east side, between West 9th and 10th Streets, showing a florist occupying an entrance to this building. This structure formerly bore No. 118-122 Sixth Ave. No. 2 of this set is similar.

September 18, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

B1 NEG: 2807

Sixth Avenue, west side, at the convergence of Christopher Street and Greenwich Avenue, showing, a diner at the southerly apex, both the new Detention House for Women at the northerly apex, opposite the W. 8th Street "El" Station. The clock tower seen is atop the Jefferson Market Court.

View No. 2 is northwestward from a vantage point on the east side of the Avenue, near Waverly Place. In this instance the "El" has been partially razed. Note the iron grille near the curbing. This is a ventilator shaft for the new subway which at this date is under construction.

January 7, 1939.
View 2: February 19, 1939.

P. L. Sperr

(3)

A view similar to No. 2 several months later. The Times of April 4, 1939 reports the renaming of this open area as "Village Square" under local legislation introduced by Councilman Howard H. Spellman. This was arrived at in a contest among villagers conducted by the Sixth Avenue Association.

It was formerly known as "Jefferson Market Square" and is at the intersection of Eighth Street, Christopher Street, Greenwich Avenue and Sixth Avenue.

May 19, 1939

P. L. Sperr

Sixth Avenue, west side, at the convergence of Christopher Street and Greenwich Avenue, showing, a diner at the southerly apex, both the new Detention House for Women at the northerly apex, opposite the W. 8th Street "El" Station. The clock tower seen is atop the Jefferson Market Court.

May 19, 1939

P. L. Sperr

Sixth Avenue, east side, south from W. 9th Street, showing mainly, the blockfront between 9th and 8th Streets. These photographs are possible since the removal of the old "El" line that formerly darkened the Avenue. The 8th Street station of same was here. A recent City Council resolution has authorized the appellation of "Village Square" to the open area remaining.

View 1: April 13, 1939
View 2: March 10, 1939
View 3: March 8, 1939

P. L. Sperr

P. L. Sperr

Sixth Avenue, north from W. 9th Street, showing demolition of the Sixth Avenue Elevated Line between its 8th and 14th Street stations.

At the left margin is a portion of the Jefferson Market Court. Note the bus at W. 10th Street and the Empire State Building tower in the center background.

P. L. Sperr

The same, from another angle.

P. L. Sperr

February 19, 1939

May 17, 1939

Sixth Avenue, north from W. 9th Street, showing demolition of the Sixth Avenue Elevated Line between its 8th and 14th Street stations.

May 17, 1939

Sixth Avenue, east side, at West 9th Street, showing the West Side Savings Bank at the N. E. corner. The building containing Rocky's Restaurant is at the S. E. corner.

May 9, 1940
Views 1,2

P. L. Sperr
